definitions.definition: To ooze or pass slowly through pores or other small openings , and in overly small quantities; said of liquids, etc.
examples: Water has seeped through the roof.
The water steadily seeped in through the thirl.

definitions.definition: To enter or penetrate slowly; to spread or diffuse .
examples: Woe seeped through her heart thinking of what had befallen their ethnic group.
Fear began to seep into the local community over the contamination of their fishpond.

definitions.definition: To diminish or wane away slowly.
examples: The resistance movement against the invaders had slowly seeped away.

definitions.definition: To allow a liquid to pass through, to leak.

main_definition: ( intransitive ) To ooze or pass slowly through pores or other small openings , and in overly small quantities; said of liquids, etc.
secondary_definitions: ( intransitive , figurative ) To enter or penetrate slowly; to spread or diffuse .
( intransitive , figurative ) To diminish or wane away slowly.
( transitive ) (of a crack etc.) To allow a liquid to pass through, to leak.
